testimony: Mr Chairperson I call Mogoera Valentine Modikoa, application number 7212/97.  His application is on page 142 of Volume 2.
Mr Modikoa, what language do you choose to use here?
Mr Modikoa, do you belong to a political party?
You are applying for amnesty for the offences of arson, attempted murder and kidnapping, is that correct?
Let's talk about the arson.  Can you tell us when this occurred and who was the victim?
It was in 1993, it was at night.  We went to Ben - Sibongele Sambo's house.  The house number is 9381, that is Sibongele Sambo's house.
Why did you burn Sibongele Sambo's house?
Sibongele was a member of the IFP.
Who were you with and who ordered you to burn Sibongele's house?
We received an order from Meneer.  I was with Jango, Mdmase and M'Africa.
That is myself, Jango, Mdmase and M'Africa.
What did you use to burn the house with?
Tell me, when you burnt the house was there anybody present?
Yes, they were present in the house.
Who was present that you know of?
That is Sibongele Sambo was present in the house.
Did you think by throwing a petrol bomb onto her house that you could endanger her life?
Now let's talk about the kidnapping incident.  Can you tell us when that occurred?

That's Sibongele Sambo.  A month after the arson we went to fetch her from Section 5.  We informed her to go with us then she denied therefore we decided to take her by force to Section 2.  When we arrived there, Ben Mashinini who was the commander, it was myself, Vuyisili and Jabu.  Then Mashinini instructed us that because we were not armed we should return.
We returned back.  We waited for those who went with her to find out what happened.
Did you know that when you were told by your commander Ben Mashinini to leave the house, did you know that Sibongele and her sister would be attacked by your comrades?
May you please repeat the question?
Sorry.  When you were told to leave along with Vuyisile and Jabu, did you know what was going to happen at the house after that?

Thank you, I have no more questions Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR SAMUELS
What did you think was going to happen there, were they going to have a party?
I thought they were going to be questioned.
May it please you, Mr Chairman.  How far apart from the others, apart from each other were your involvements in the two incidents pertaining to Sibongele?  How far apart in time?
So you were involved in two incidents pertaining to Sibongele in a space of one month apart from each other and you testified that knew her well, is that true?
Now look at your application on page 144.  Let me first ask you, who filled out this application, whose handwriting is this?
There was somebody who was filling in that form but I was instructing him what to do.
What's the name of this person filling in a form?
That is George, I don't know his surname Sir.
But you instructed him what to fill out here, what to write here on this paper, is that right?

Then why do you say under the question
"State whether any persons was injured, killed or suffered any damage to the property as the result of such acts?"
"Yes, but I don't know their names, they were killed when we were defending.  Why is that?
May you please repeat the question?

I want to know from you, if you knew Sibongele well and you were involved in two attacks in the space of one month at the same premises on this person, why don't you disclose her name in your application?  Is it perhaps because when you filled out this application you did not have this specific incident in mind?
I knew that it was Sibongele.  I did not know her sister's identity.  I filled these forms after I've received their names.
Did you have the incident that you gave evidence about or the incidents that you gave evidence about in mind when you gave George instructions to fill out these forms?
I was not writing about those two incidents.
You were not writing about them did you say?
Chairperson, the interpreter suspects that the applicant doesn't hear correctly, maybe if they can change his earphones?  He must be on channel 3, please put him on channel 3.
Are you able to hear properly now?  Are you able to hear properly.
You should answer, the machine can't take up your nodding of your head, so you say yes or no.
Can I start from the third question?
Of the mechanisms are operating properly.
Now can the witness hear from the phones what is being asked?

Now the most important question that is being recently asked is when you filled in this form, or when this form was being completed, were you talking or were you referring to the incidents relating to the burning and attempted murder as you referred to in respect of Miss Sibongele Sambo and a month thereafter the kidnapping, were you referring to those incidents after you completed the application or some other incident?
Yes I was referring to them because we filled this form after we did those incidents then at that time when I filled this form I didn't know their identity.
But I thought you said when you got the order to go kidnap then you knew who you must go kidnap, no so?
Yes I knew that we were going to Extension 5 but I did not have the full information about the identity of the person we're going to kidnap.
Who were you going to kidnap?
I only heard when the commander instructed us that we should go and kidnap Sibongele.
I knew that the commander knew the person, he has the full information about the identity of that person.
I'm talking about you, did you know who he was talking about?
When did you find out who Sibongele was by name?
I knew after - when we were filling, after we had filled the forms.

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Now the first attack, the arson attack that you carried out on Sibongele's house, who did you receive your orders from?
On arson the order came from Mr Meneer.
And at that stage who was the commander of Section 2 or Extension 2?
It was both Meneer and Ben Mashinini.
Now when you threw the petrol bomb to Sibongele's house, you said you knew she was inside, is that correct?
Was anybody else inside the house?
I did not know as to whether there were other people in the house but we knew that Sibongele was in the house but we did not know as to whether there were other people in the house.
Did you look yourself?  Did you look through the window before you threw the bomb?
How did you know only Sibongele was in the house or how did you know Sibongele was in the house, who told you?
There were members of Inkatha who were drinking alcohol in the house therefore I knew that they would not entertain themselves in her house in her absence.
So you knew that there were other people who you say were members of the Inkatha Freedom Party in the house?
They would entertain themselves during the day and they left.  I did not know as whether all of them left the house but we had the belief that Sibongele was in the house.
But if they've left early and you don't know when they've left, how would you know whether she's still there or whether she left with them?
They were in the car, we were watching when the car left then we confirmed that he was not inside the car.
Alright, you received orders to go and burn a house while you knew she was inside and you're applying for Amnesty for attempted murder.  Is that in respect of that offence of the house burning?
So your instructions was to go and kill her by burning the house in which she was at that stage, is that correct?
Now did you hear whether you succeeded or not?  Where did you hear she was still alive the first time?
I knew the following day that she survived.
So would it be correct to say that approximately a month later when you got instructions to kidnap her, you were aware of the fact that your leadership wanted her dead?
May you please repeat your question?

Am I correct to say that when you got the instructions approximately a month later to go and kidnap her, you were aware of the fact that your leadership wanted her dead.  In fact you already tried to kill her once?
Now why do you tell the Commission that you were under the impression that you were to kidnap her to take her away for questioning?
When we tried to inform her that she should go with us, she denied then therefore we had to kidnap her.
Yes, but how did it come that you believed that she was to be taken away for kidnapping - for questioning and not to be shot?
Because he had claimed that he was a member of the ANC and she was lying.
What was the accusation against Sibongele?  Why did you have to kill her when you threw the petrol bomb at her house?
It's because members of the IFP were burning members of the ANC in the community therefore we had to retaliate by burning an IFP members house.
Wasn't it general knowledge amongst both you and your comrades, the members of the group that were instructed to kidnap Sibongele that she was a person whom your leadership wanted to be dead?
May you please repeat your question?
Wasn't it common knowledge amongst you and your comrades that your leadership wanted Sibongele dead when you went to kidnap her?
Do you say it was common knowledge that our leadership wanted Sibongele to be killed when we kidnapped her?
Listen could you kindly listen now.  She was regarded as an enemy of the ANC is that correct?
So you received orders to act against her?
And the first order was to burn her house?
And if she's inside the house she should be killed with the burning, is that correct?
So you knew that this person being seen as an enemy should be killed at one stage or another?
At the time when we were throwing the petrol bombs to her house, we wanted to kill her.
Yes and therefore at the time you kidnapped her you knew that the ANC wanted her dead, not so?
At the time when we kidnapped her I knew that she was going to be interrogated about her claim that she's a supporter of the ANC.
But you knew they wanted to kill her a month before already?
Yes, at that time I knew.
So it's not an issue of a question that you only thought they want to question her, you knew in all likelihood she was going to be killed?
Yes I knew that there was that possibility for her to be killed.
And further, was it not for the fact that you did not carry a gun that day, you would have been present at the attack on her, is that correct?
Now just one point that came up now.  How did you know she was going to claim to be an ANC supporter?
I think you misunderstand Mr Swanepoel.  The day of the kidnapping, somehow she had already made that assertion and she was going to be questioned about this assertion.

As you please Mr Chairman.  I have nothing further.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR SWANEPOEL
When you received your orders, can you tell us exactly what Meneer had said to you?
You mean about the order for assault or for the kidnapping?  It was at night in 1993, as I've explained that I was with Jango and Mdmase and Mafrica.  We arrived at her place ...(intervention)
Never mind about that, Ms Patel will probably ask you about that just now.  What did Meneer say must happen?
He instructed us to go and burn that house, that's what he said to us.
Did he say whether Sibongele must die or not?
Please, that's what we're asking, the full instruction.
He instructed us that we should throw petrol bombs in that house so that she should be burnt together with her house because as supporters of the IFP we were burning the houses.
Did he explain that that is why you were to go and burn her house and kill her if possible?
Did he give you the name of the person whose house you should go and burn and who should be killed with the burning?  Did he mention any name?
He told us that we should go at Sibongele's house.
Did he specifically say that you should go to Sibongele's house?
So you knew whose house it was?
Yes as he has mentioned the name and again the house number I knew.
So before you acted you knew her name and before you kidnapped her you knew her name, is that correct?
Yes but I did not know the identity of Sibongele, I only knew the name.
So when you filled in this form you knew her name?
I knew the name but I did not know the identity of the person.
When you kidnapped her you had the name and you had the person together so you knew the name and the identity because here you have got the two together?
I will say it for the second time, I forgot her name because everytime I when I was filling these forms I was filling them with somebody else.
At the time of the kidnapping what were your specific instructions then from Meneer?
He said we should talk with her peacefully and take her from Extension 5 to Extension 2 and go with her.
Who did he say should talk with her unless specific instructions regarding that?
No she did not mention a person responsible for talking to her it's an order.
So in terms of the general order the possibility existed at that stage that you might have been one of those people who would have questioned her?

Given that at the stage when you received the order to kidnap, right, you say that Meneer gave a general order that she should be questioned.  What I'm putting to you is that there is then given that, there's the possibility that you would have been one of those people who would have questioned her, is that correct?
Okay, so the order was not only for you to kidnap, the order was for you to question her as well?
The instruction was that we should go and take her at her place at Extension 5.
Were you supposed to question her as well?
We arrived and informed her that we should leave, then she denied therefore we had to take her by force to Extension 2.
Okay, let me try again.  After she was supposed to be kidnapped, what did Meneer say should happen to her exactly?

Mr Chairperson, if I may interject here.  According to my client's instructions or according to his evidence in chief he testified that the incident of the kidnapping was ordered by Ben Mashinini.  My learned friend is still I think leading him on the fact that Meneer gave the specific order whereas Meneer gave the order regarding the arson of the house which occurred a month before.  Thank you.
Whoever gave the order for the kidnapping, were you supposed to have interrogated her as well?
No, we tried to talk to her so that we should go to Extension 2, therefore that is why we had to take her by force.  We were not supposed to question her but just to instruct her to go with us.
Is all that Ben had said to you, that that was the full extent of your instructions?

Thank you Honourable Chairperson.

I didn't know whose house was that in Extension 5.

Yes, that is 9381 that is her house number.  That Extension 5, I didn't know whose house was that.
